choices.C: Submit a PUT to the /api/fdm/latest/devicesettings/pushpolicy URI.
choices.A: Submit a POST to the /api/fdm/latest/operational/deploy URI.
choices.D: Submit a POST to the /api/fdm/latest/devicesettings/pushpolicy URI.
choices.B: Submit a GET to the /api/fdm/latest/operational/deploy URI.

discussion.content:
A is correct

Step 1 
Use the POST /operational/deploy resource in the Deployment group to initiate a deployment.

For example, the curl command would look like the following:


curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' 
--header 'Accept: application/json'
'https://ftd.example.com/api/fdm/latest/operational/deploy'

See: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/ftd-api/guide/ftd-rest-api/ftd-api-deployment.html

questions.question_text: After changes are made to the Cisco Firepower Threat Defense configuration using the Cisco Firepower Device Manager API, what must be done to ensure that the new policy is activated?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct

Endpoint: /api/v2/search/submissions
Each artifact that has been submitted to Threat Grid for analysis has an associated Submission record. These records store meta-data about the artifact, its analysis run, the 'observables' (or 'entities') that were seen during the analysis, and any behavioral indicators triggered by those observations.

Request Parameters
q false string query Query text.

questions.question_text:

//IMG//

discussion.content: @alainJ, Your idea is right but execution is wrong. If you look at option D closely, the Python dictionary object is string-quoted '{"ipAddress": "10.0.0.50"}' so that it can be encoded and added as parameterized url string
correct is C since data=str.encode(payload) is used (encode function requires a string, not a python dictionary).
